questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thyroglossal cyst is congenital in origin and can occur anywhere along the course of the thyroglossal tract, most common site of thyroglossal cyst is subhyoid . As the thyroglossal tract extends from the base of tongue to isthumus, so when a person swallows the cyst moves and makes the cyst move with it and when you protrude the tongue the cyst moves with it. And when we consider the treatment option we have to do a Sistrunk operation, which involves excision of the cyst and the tract and removal of the hyoid body. So Option A is wrong as the thyroglossal cyst moves with deglutition.

questions.text: Most common site of thyroglossal cyst: (AIIMS Nov 15)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Thyroglossal cyst can occur at any location along the thyroglossal tract but the most common site of occurance of thyroglossal cyst is subhyoid. This is the reason while operating a patient of thyroglossal cyst we have to do excision of the body of the hyoid bone as the the tract passes through it(sistrunk surgery).

questions.text: Thyroglossal cyst may occasionally give rise to carcinoma:(LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) If a person has a long standing thyroglossal cyst then there is a chance that patients might develop papillary carcinoma of thyroid in the cyst. Medullary carcinoma of thyroid arises from C cells of thyroid. It has no relation to thyroglossal cyst . Follicular carcinoma of thyroid arises in a long standing goiter in an iodine deficient area. It has no relation to thyroglossal cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following is the agent of choice for treating thyrotoxicosis during pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Hyperthyroidism in pregnancy should be aggressively evaluated and treated. • It is most commonly caused by Graves disease, but autonomously functioning nodules, gestational trophoblastic disease, thyroiditis, and hyperemesis gravidarum should also be considered. • Hyperthyroidism is most difficult to control in the first trimester of pregnancy and easiest to control in the third trimester. • Methimazole crosses the placenta to a greater degree than propylthiouracil and has been associated with fetal aplasia cutis and choanal atresia. • Treatment of choice is propylthiouracil. • Radioiodine should not be used during pregnancy, either for scanning or treatment, because of effects on the fetal thyroid. Overall DOC in pregnancy:-propylthiouracil. DOC in 1st trimester:-propylthiouracil DOC in 2nd and 3rd trimester:-methimazole.

questions.text: A 21-years old woman has 3 cm node in the lower deep cervical chain of the left side. The biopsy is interpreted as revealing normal thyroid tissue in a lymph node. The most likely diagnosis is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) This case scenario talks about a patient who has cervical lymphnode enlargement which shows a thyroid tissue on biopsy. This denotes a lateral cervical lymphadenopathy in a case of papillary carcinoma of thyroid. Cervical lymph node enlargement in a papillary carcinoma of thyroid is called as lateral aberrant thyroid. Option A is wrong as sub acute thyroiditis presents with pain, it does not presents with lymph node enlargement. Option B is also wrong, this lymph node enlargement is because of the spread of the cancer from papillary carcinoma of thyroid to the cervical lymph nodes but this is not referred as a metastatic disease. It is just the lymph node enlargement and has good prognosis if it is treated timely. Option C is false as hashimoto’s thyroididtis does not have a lymph node enlargement .

questions.text: A well differentiated follicular carcinoma of thyroid can be best differentiated from a follicular adenoma by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) To differentiate between follicular carcinoma of thyroid and follicular adenoma we have to go for tissue biopsy in which we look for vascular invasion. We can not differentiate between those two on the basis of FNAC as FNAC can not help us look at vascular invasion. Hurthle cell carcinoma is basically a type of follicular carcinoma of thyroid. In hurthle cell tumour we have a characteristic hurthle or askanazy cells which are characteristic of this tumor. Lining of cell type and nuclear features can not help to distinguish between the follicular carcinoma and adenoma.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is evaluated for a rapidly enlarging neck mass. The patient takes levothyroxine replacement. Despite no change in her medication dosage, she has been experiencing fevers, night sweats, and weight loss. Ultrasound reveals a 4-cm left thyroid mass with a pseudocystic pattern. FNA is nondiagnostic. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Primary thyroid lymphoma is rare (<1% of all thyroid malignancies). There is an increased association between lymphoma and Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. In the current patient, the presence of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, a rapidly enlarging mass, and the constitutional symptoms are highly suggestive of primary thyroid lymphoma. If FNA fails to yield a diagnosis on the first attempt, it has been shown that repeated FNA is unlikely to be diagnostic in subsequent attempts. Observation is not an appropriate step in the management of any patient with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. Performing open or core biopsy is a feasible option in these circumstances and would more likely provide an adequate cell yield to complete flow cytometry and establish monoclonality. Treatment varies between chemotherapy and surgical ablation. Resection is typically reserved for patients who fail to respond to chemotherapy or have completed their course of adjuvant therapy and demonstrated incomplete regression of disease. If surgery is planned, total thyroidectomy should be performed, followed by chemotherapy.

questions.text: A patient with autoimmune thyroiditis present with hypothyroidism. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thyroid peroxidase antibodies In a patient with autoimmune thyroiditis (like Hashimoto's thyroiditis) presenting with hypothyroidism, the true statement is that thyroid peroxidase antibodies are commonly found. While thyroid enlargement can be painless, it is not always significant and is more typical of Hashimoto's. Autoimmune thyroiditis is predominantly more common in women than men, and there is a slight increased risk of thyroid cancer associated with Hashimoto's, contrary to the notion of no malignant risk.

questions.text: What is the condition most commonly associated with elevated TSH levels and decreased T4 levels?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hashimoto's thyroiditis Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland, leading to chronic inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue. This results in decreased production of thyroid hormones, including T4. As a compensatory mechanism, the pituitary gland releases more TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland, causing increased TSH levels.
